jitobear

Everything mentioned above is good.
 
 I think the French Revolution should replace the American Revolution tho. The French Revolution and Age of Enlightenment is where it began - the idealogies that led to the American Revolution.
 
 My history prof always said there were "heros of histories" - people who changed the world completely (not all were "good guys"). He placed Christ, Mohammed and Columbus at the top of his list.
sanguinekane
The French revolution was after the American revolution.
Duo_Maxwell
True, but the American revolution didn't lead to the overthrow or massive uprising aganist monarchial tyrants.
sanguinekane

Yes, but jitobear's comment was thus:
 
 
 The French Revolution and Age of Enlightenment is where it began - the idealogies that led to the American Revolution. 

 
 Ideas formulated in the Frnech revolution cannot have an effect on the American revolution, as the American version came 13 years before the French one. It's a fact.
 
 Not that I don't agree with him on the rest of his points, but the simple truth is the American revolution was of our own making, not inspired by the French.
Redratio1
Hell you might as well include the Haitian revolution. The first successful anti-colonial revolution.
Modern_Republic

True, but the American revolution didn't lead to the overthrow or massive uprising aganist monarchial tyrants.

 
 It led to the overthrow of British imperialism in America. That's about it.. I guess I shouldn't say 'about' as that was a pretty huge feat.
Obvious Child

'British imperialism in America' is a joke. The people rebelling for the large part considered themselves British citizens, at least at first. They were protected by the British armed forces and refused to pay to support them. To be more accurate, there were a few semio-criminal merchants who were against the tariffs and stirred the whole thing up. The true imperialism was against the native peoples, and one of the bones of contention in the revolution was the British authorities refusal to support American desires to expand into territories that had been agreed by treaty to belong to the Indians. The racist element was brought out in a recent history programme showing a classic picture of the first American patriot 'martyrs' (protesters who baited soldiers, who opened fire). The names are listed, but the Native American who was killed is drawn as white and several of the soldiers are shown as black or Native American which is unlikely historically.
 
 Also, calling Columbus one of the great heroes of history along with Christ and Mohammed is a joke, and ridiculously Americo-centric. What about Marx? Luther? Hitler? If Columbous hadn't come along someone else would have.
 
 As far as explorers go I'd say Raleigh, as he's responsible for the popularity of tobacco, rather than marijuana. that could have effected history a lot.

you guys are forgetting something major. probably not a single moment but still: slavery, colonization . . i guess you could call it the rape of africa. most african american depravity can be traced back to slavery and the jim crow laws. many of the problems going on in africa can be traced back to actions of the colonists. if any of you have seen hotel rawanda you'd understand. now i'm not trying to be an apologist for the murderers there, but the belgians need to take some of the blame. if you haven't seen it, this is what they did . . .the colonists separated the africans into 2 groups based purerly on physical characteristics-hutus and tutsis-the tutsis were the preferred "race" and were given all the power postition in the colony. this caused the hutus to resent the tutsis and helll for the tutsis as soon as the belgians left the colony.
